raw_text:
Ferrero eyes return to top form
 
 Former world number one Juan Carlos Ferrero insists he can get back to his best despite a tough start to 2005.
 
 The 2003 French Open champion has slipped to 64 in the world after a year of illness and injuries in 2004, but is confident that his form will return. "I don't know when it is going to happen," Ferrero told BBC Sport. "But I have a lot of confidence in me that I will be the same Juan Carlos as I was before, and very soon. I feel 100% again mentally." The 25-year-old Spaniard joins a top field for the ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament in Rotterdam this week as he looks to add to just two wins in 2005. He opens against Rainer Schuettler and potentially faces fourth seed David Nalbandian in the second round. "Because I'm no longer seeded it's tougher," Ferrero admitted. "I had to play against Joachim Johansson in the first round last week in Marseille.
 
 "In the past when I was a top seed I would have played a match like that in the quarters or semi-finals. "This is the big difference but I have to do it to get higher in the rankings." Despite this, Ferrero insists he is feeling positive after chicken pox and a rib injury destroyed last season. "Physically I am 100% since December of last year," said Ferrero. "I was working very hard before the Davis Cup final to prepare and I've felt 100% from then until now. "The difficult moments were when I knew that I had the chicken pox and that it would take two or three months to recover. "I had to start from zero again physically because the virus left me at zero per cent. "When I started to come back I had my rib broken when I fell on court and that was another two months out. Those five months were pretty difficult for me."
 
 Among the low points of a difficult year for Ferrero was the decision of Spain captain Jordi Arrese to drop him for the Davis Cup final against the USA. "It was difficult because I had been playing well for the whole year and the coaches told me that I would play," said Ferrero. "But then I had some problems with my hand two days before the Friday matches so they decided to choose Nadal instead. "It was difficult for me not to be in the Friday matches but I had to understand. "Inside me I wanted to play but this was the decision of the captain and they had to make it."
llama3.2:1b:
Juan Carlos Ferrero, a former world number one tennis player, returned to form last year after a tough start due to illness and injuries. Despite being ranked 64 at the end of 2004, he is confident that his physical condition has improved significantly since December last year and is now 100% mentally.

Ferrero will compete in the ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament in Rotterdam next week and faces Rainer Schuettler and potentially David Nalbandian in the second round. He was dropped from the Davis Cup team after a difficult year, but has since recovered and is looking to add to his two wins in 2005.

Ferrero has also overcome other setbacks, including chicken pox and a rib injury that caused him significant time off due to its duration. Despite these challenges, he feels positive about his current form and believes he will return to the top of his game soon.
llama3.2:3b: Juan Carlos Ferrero expects to regain his form despite a tough start to 2005 after recovering from illness and injuries that kept him out for five months in 2004, feeling fully recovered mentally and confident he can return as one of the world's top players.
gemma2:2b: Juan Carlos Ferrero, former world number one, is confident he can return to his best form despite a challenging start to 2005. He is currently ranked 64th in the world after injuries and illness affected his year in 2004.  He will be competing at the ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament this week, facing challenges as a non-seeded player. Ferrero acknowledges that the absence of seeding creates tougher matches but he remains positive about his physical recovery. He cites personal challenges like chicken pox and a rib injury as contributing to a difficult year, but emphasizes his commitment to regaining top form through hard work. The decision to withdraw from the Davis Cup final due to hand problems was also a significant setback for Ferrero.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Juan Carlos Ferrero has returned to his best form, having slipped to 64 in the world after a year of illness and injuries in 2004. He believes he will be back as top of the rankings for the ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament. Despite a difficult start, Ferrero is confident that his physical and mental condition will return soon.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former world number one Juan Carlos Ferrero aims to return to top form after a 2004 injury and illness season, feeling confident his performance will improve soon. Despite facing tough competition in the Rotterdam tournament, including defending champion David Nalbandian, Ferrero remains motivated by returning from chicken pox and rib injuries in December.
qwen2.5:3b: Former world number one Juan Carlos Ferrero, despite slipping to 64th in the world rankings due to illness and injuries in 2004, insists he can return to his former form. Currently focusing on the ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament in Rotterdam, Ferrero plans to face tough competition including potential encounters with fourth seed David Nalbandian. He acknowledges the challenge of not being a top seed but remains positive about his recovery from chicken pox and rib injury last year. Ferrero notes that while physical recovery was crucial, emotional resilience has also been key as he continues his comeback journey after difficult personal setbacks in 2005.

He hopes to add two more wins in Rotterdam as he opens against Rainer Schuettler and potentially faces David Nalbandian in the second round. Despite being no longer seeded, Ferrero is determined to make his presence felt by playing tougher matches like he did against Joachim Johansson in Marseille last week. He admits that it's challenging but believes he can do it to get higher in the rankings. Physically, he has recovered from chicken pox and a rib injury since December of last year and is 100% again mentally. Although he faced tough moments during his road back to top form like having the virus leave him at zero per cent and breaking his ribs while falling on court, Ferrero remained focused on his goal of playing well for the Spain Davis Cup team. However, he was not chosen to play in the final against the USA due to an injury two days before the matches, which was a low point in a difficult year for him.
